metadata.title: W3Schools.com

metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: XML Attributes
XML elements can have attributes, just like HTML.
content.html: XML elements can have attributes, just like HTML.

content.text: Attributes are designed to contain data related to a specific element.
content.html: Attributes are designed to contain data related to a specific element.

content.text: XML Attributes Must be Quoted
Attribute values must always be quoted. Either single or double quotes can be used.
content.html: Attribute values must always be quoted. Either single or double quotes can be used.

content.text: For a person's gender, the <person> element can be written like this:
content.html: For a person's gender, the <person> element can be written like this:

content.code_html: <person gender="female">

content.text: or like this:

content.code_html: <person gender='female'>

content.text: If the attribute value itself contains double quotes you can use single quotes, like in this example:
content.html: If the attribute value itself contains double quotes you can use single quotes, like in this example:

content.code_html: <gangster name='George "Shotgun" Ziegler'>

content.text: or you can use character entities:

content.code_html: <gangster name="George "Shotgun" Ziegler">

content.text: XML Elements vs. Attributes
Take a look at these two examples:
content.html: Take a look at these two examples:

content.code_html:
<person gender="female">
  <firstname>Anna</firstname>
  <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>

<person>
  <gender>female</gender>
  <firstname>Anna</firstname>
  <lastname>Smith</lastname>
</person>

content.text: In the first example, gender is an attribute. In the last example, gender is an element. Both examples provide the same information.
content.html: In the first example, gender is an attribute. In the last example, gender is an element. Both examples provide the same information.

content.text: There are no rules about when to use attributes or when to use elements in XML.
content.html: There are no rules about when to use attributes or when to use elements in XML.

content.text: My Favorite Way
The following three XML documents contain exactly the same information:
content.html: The following three XML documents contain exactly the same information:

content.text: A date attribute is used in the first example:
content.html: A date attribute is used in the first example:

content.code_html:
<note date="2008-01-10">
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
</note>

content.text: A <date> element is used in the second example:
content.html: A <date> element is used in the second example:

content.code_html:
<note>
  <date>2008-01-10</date>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
</note>

content.text: An expanded <date> element is used in the third example: (THIS IS MY FAVORITE):
content.html: An expanded <date> element is used in the third example: (THIS IS MY FAVORITE):

content.code_html:
<note>
  <date>
    <year>2008</year>
    <month>01</month>
    <day>10</day>
  </date>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
</note>

content.text: Avoid XML Attributes?
Some things to consider when using attributes are:
content.html: Some things to consider when using attributes are:

content.text: Don't end up like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<note day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.code:
<note day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

</note>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<note day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.code_html:
<note day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">
</note>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<note day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!">

day="10" month="01" year="2008"
to="Tove" from="Jani" heading="Reminder"
body="Don't forget me this weekend!"

content.text: XML Attributes for Metadata
Sometimes ID references are assigned to elements. These IDs can be used to identify XML elements in much the same way as the id attribute in HTML. This example demonstrates this:
content.html: Sometimes ID references are assigned to elements. These IDs can be used to identify XML elements in much the same way as the id attribute in HTML. This example demonstrates this:

content.code:
<messages>


<note id="501">


<to>Tove</to>


<from>Jani</from>


<heading>Reminder</heading>


<body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>


</note>


<note id="502">


<to>Jani</to>


<from>Tove</from>


<heading>Re: Reminder</heading>


<body>I will not</body>


</note>

</messages>
content.code_html:
<messages>
  <note id="501">
    <to>Tove</to>
    <from>Jani</from>
    <heading>Reminder</heading>
    <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
  </note>
  <note id="502">
    <to>Jani</to>
    <from>Tove</from>
    <heading>Re: Reminder</heading>
    <body>I will not</body>
  </note>
</messages>

content.text: The id attributes above are for identifying the different notes. It is not a part of the note itself.
content.html: The id attributes above are for identifying the different notes. It is not a part of the note itself.

content.text: What I'm trying to say here is that metadata (data about data) should be stored as attributes, and the data itself should be stored as elements.
content.html: What I'm trying to say here is that metadata (data about data) should be stored as attributes, and the data itself should be stored as elements.
